title: Eurostat scandal
text:
In 2000, internal auditors raised concerns about fictitious <a href="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>'s contracts with outside companies and referred the matter to the European Anti-Fraud Office, <a href="OLAF">OLAF</a>. OLAF did not react.
In 2001, <a href="Paul%20van%20Buitenen">Paul van Buitenen</a>, whose earlier report had indirectly led to the resignation of the previous Santer <a href="European%20Commission">Commission</a>, produced a second report, but this at first led to no action, until <a href="Hans-Martin%20Tillack">Hans-Martin Tillack</a> and the press started to take interest in the matter. Questions were asked in the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a>, OLAF produced a new report entitled "A vast enterprise for looting community funds" as it was reported by <a href="Financial%20Times">Financial Times</a> on May 16, 2003.
Finally the Prodi Commission acted. Three senior Eurostat officials were removed from their posts and a number of contracts with outside companies were cancelled.
It was alleged that, at least during the 1990s, Eurostat used a double <a href="accounting%20system">accounting system</a> to transfer large amounts of money to secret <a href="bank%20account">bank account</a>s not monitored by auditors and that the value of some contracts was inflated. Allegedly there was evidence of <a href="cronyism">cronyism</a> and financial irregularities, though no evidence of personal enrichment was found. Between four and five million <a href="euro">euro</a>s was thought to have been "siphoned off", mostly between 1996 and 2001. Some of the money was recovered.
On July 8, 2008 the European Commission was condemned by the <a href="European%20Court%20of%20Justice">European Court of Justice</a> for several failures of OLAF.
The Commission had to pay €56,000 to two senior Eurostat officials.
